note: German neurologist who collaborated with Nissl, Erb, and Kraepelin. Anton’s syndrome: visual anosognosia. G. Anton, Austrian neurologist.
title: Adie pupil: large pupil reacting slowly to light and accommodation
Alzheimer’s disease: most common cause of dementia

container-title: M. Benedikt, Austrian physician and soldier. Berry aneurysm. J. Berry, English surgeon. Binswanger’s dementia: widespread cerebral small vessel disease. O. Binswanger, German psychiatrist
note: Bourneville’s disease: tuberous sclerosis. D. Bourneville, French neurologist. Broca’s aphasia: expressive aphasia. P. Broca, French surgeon and Darwinist. Brodmann areas: cytoarchitectural map of the brain. K. Brodmann, German
title: Argyll Robertson pupil: syphilitic pupil that ‘accommodates but doesn’t react’
Scottish physician and golfer. Arnold–Chiari syndrome: congenital inferior displacement of cerebellar tonsils
Babinski sign: stroking lateral aspect of sole resulting in plantar extension of big toe
Polish neurologist, pupil of Charcot. Bassen–Kornzweig disease: ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa
Battle’s sign: bruising over mastoid suggesting fractured base of skull

Beevor’s sign: excessive displacement of umbilicus on attempted sit-up due to weakness of abdominal musculature. C. Beevor, English neurologist. Bell’s palsy: idiopathic lower motor neuron paralysis of facial nerve
Scottish surgeon, accomplished artist, founder of the Middlesex Hospital. Benedikt’s syndrome: ipsilateral oculomotor palsy with contralateral ataxia

author.literal: Charcot, French neurologist. Described multiple sclerosis, MND, and ankle clonus. Taught P. Marie, Babinski, and Freud. P. Marie, French neurologist. H. Tooth, English physician, keen musician, and carpenter. Cheyne–Stokes breathing: alternating hyperpnoea and apnoea. J. Cheyne, Scottish physician. W. Stokes, Irish physician.

note: waiter’s tip sign). A. Dejerine-Klumpke, French neurologist. Dejerine anterior bulbar palsy: anterior spinal artery occlusion; Dejerine–Landouzy dystrophy (FSH); Dejerine–Sottas neuropathy (HMSN III); and Dejerine–Thomas atrophy (OPCA). J. Dejerine, French neurologist and amateur boxer. Dercum’s disease: lipomas and neuropathy. F. Dercum, US neurologist. Devic’s disease: optic neuritis and myelopathy. E. Devic, French physician. Duane’s syndrome: developmental anomaly leading to contraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on attempted abduction of the affected eye. A. Duane, US ophthalmologist. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: X-linked muscular dystrophy. G. Duchenne, eccentric peripatetic French neurologist who invented the punch muscle biopsy. Eaton–Lambert myasthenic syndrome: weakness, post-tetanic facilitation, associated with voltage-gated calcium-channel antibodies. L. Eaton, US neurologist. E. Lambert, US neurophysiologist. Edinger–Westphal nucleus: autonomic nucleus of oculomotor nerve. L. Edinger, German neurologist and hypnotist. C. Westphal, German
title: Canavan’s disease: infantile dysmyelination with macrocephaly
Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease: peroneal muscular atrophy/HMSN
Chvostek’s sign: tapping skin over facial nerve induces muscle twitching; seen in tetany and anxiety
Claude syndrome: ipsilateral oculomotor palsy with contralateral ataxia and chorea due to lesion in red nucleus
French neurologist and colleague of Lhermitte. Cockayne syndrome: dwarfism, microcephaly, dermatitis, deafness, pyramidal and cerebellar signs

English paediatrician and entomologist. Collet–Sicard syndrome: jugular foramen syndrome involving 9th to 2th cranial nerves). F. Collet, French otolaryngologist. Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease: rapid-onset dementia due to abnormal prion protein
Dandy–Walker syndrome: maldevelopment of foramina of Luschka and Magendie leading to hydrocephalus
Dejerine-Klumpke syndrome: lower brachial plexus palsy

container-title: G. Werdnig, Austrian neurologist. J. Hoffman, German neurologist. Wernicke’s encephalopathy
K. Wernicke, German physician. West syndrome: infantile spasms. W
note: R. Todd, Irish physician. Tolosa–Hunt syndrome: orbital pseudotumour.

West, English physician. Wilks syndrome: myasthenia gravis. S. Wilks, English physician. Circle of Willis: arterial anastomosis at base of brain. T. Willis, English physician and Royalist. Wilson’s disease: hepatolenticular degeneration. S. Kinnier Wilson, US neurologist who advised ‘Never believe what the patient says the doctor said’. Appendix 4 611
title: Todd’s paresis: transient weakness following a focal epileptic seizure
Turcot syndrome: familial intestinal polyps and gliomas
Unverricht–Lundborg disease: Baltic myoclonus
Vernet’s syndrome: paresis of glossopharyngeal, vagal
French neurologist. Villaret’s syndrome: paresis of glossopharyngeal, vagal, accessory, and hypoglossal nerves with additional sympathetic involvement
Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome: poliosis, deafness, uveitis and meningitis
Japanese ophthalmologists. von Hippel–Lindau disease: cerebellar haemangioblastomas with retinal and renal angiomas
Wallenberg’s syndrome: posterior inferior cerebellar artery thrombosis
Wallerian degeneration: degeneration of nerve fibre following axonotmesis
Weber’s syndrome: ipsilateral oculomotor palsy with contralateral hemiplegia due to midbrain lesion
German physician and founder of climatotherapy. Werdnig–Hoffman disease: spinal muscular atrophy
ophthalmoplegia, delirium, and ataxia due to thiamine deficiency
